Spent quite a bit of time working on this problem. Not too successful.

Go =
to Metatrader4.com and learn the meta trader language (pretty much c). It w=
ill allow you create scripts and backtest with historical data to see how t=
hey perform. If you write a DLL you can even call NEAT via Metatrader.

I u=
sed to work for a company trading futures and I can tell you all the easy d=
ata mining type trading strategies are tapped out. You'll have to find some=
thing interesting to make it work. Ideally some sort of leading indicator o=
r something very strongly co-ordinated so you can do pairs trading.

Slidin=
g window would be my advise. But that is a pretty inconsequential detail as=
 you'll need much more than a sliding window to make money in my experience=
.

Tell me how you do and I can give you my advice. Though take it with a g=
rain of salt because I didn't make my billions through this :)

Regards,

S=
hane

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "gururise" <gururise@...> wrote:
>
> Hel=
lo,
> Browsing the archives, its obvious other's have worked on this proble=
m using NEAT with varying degrees of success.  I'm using the rtNeat C++ pac=
kage under linux and am trying to evolve a time-series predictor applicable=
 to either the stock market or forex markets.
> 
> Most of the published re=
search used Neural Networks trained via backprop.  These networks typically=
 used a sliding window technique. For example, if you have 1000 days of his=
torical data, a sliding window of 100 would feed the first 100 days of data=
 as input, and the 101st day would be the predicted output from the net. Th=
en the window would slide by 1 day, and you feed the next 100 days and so o=
n an so forth.  
> 
> I've been trying to use a similar technique with NEAT=
 with very limited success.  For inputs, I use change in price and normaliz=
ed volume.  The fitness function is basically the inverse of the mean squar=
ed error of the predicted outputs vs. the actual data.  The output is tryin=
g to predict the change in price at the next time period (it could be posit=
ive or negative).  I've also switched from the default sigmoid activation f=
unction to a bi-polar sigmoid activation that allows for outputs in the ran=
ge of [-1,1].
> 
> How are others using NEAT for time series prediction?  A=
re you using a sliding window technique, or just have a large input with on=
e output?  Has anyone had success using NEAT to evolve a time-series predic=
tor?
>
